author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't a new risk from the point of view of the user.  Users give unlimited unrevokable access to whatever tool they give their private key to, limited only by the code of the tool.  3074/7702 without in-protocol cancellation the user will give unlimited unrevokable access to whatever tool they authorize, limited only by the code of that tool.  The only difference is where the code runs (on chain vs off-chain).

author: _shemnon
content: It's not the tool, it's the tool's output that is the issue.  There have also been recent major bugs in tools and contracts, as well as supply chain attacks.  Moving this level of trust up to the tool is the issue.

author: sky.cactus
content: Off-chain tools can also have a bug.

author: sky.cactus
content: That doesn't make them safer, arguably makes them less safe because off-chain tends to have a bigger attack surface (like supply chain attacks opened up due to mutability of modern OSs).

author: _shemnon
content: So why should we bring off-chain patterns on-chain if the attack surface is larger?

author: sky.cactus
content:
Hey wallet, here is my private key, do whatever you are coded to do.
Hey Invoker, here is a signed message, do whatever you are coded to do.

author: sky.cactus
content: Attack surface is bigger off-chain.  By allowing on-chain controlled access to an account, we provide a safer alternative to giving private keys to a wallet (not to mention more capable, like atomic transactions).

author: _shemnon
content: Yes, 4337 does that nicely.  Without protocol changes

author: _shemnon
content: There are also other means that don't require protocol changes.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the best argument against these is that they take with out of the sail of people trying to get full AA working, and really we should be focusing on that for many reasons (like quantum resistance).
